Author: FuzzyCub20

Comment: This is one of those issues where it's hard to know for sure if Trump is just vomiting words without thinking about them, or if he's being serious.  If it's the latter, and if he does intend to use military force to acquire Greenland, it will be a massive blow to his presidency and party.  The GOP Congress may be spineless when it comes to a lot of his actions, but this would effectively collapse NATO and potentially trigger a larger war.  That is very different from caving to Trump's cabinet picks.  So I don't see Congress going along with it; there is already some pushback against his budget and some of his other foreign policy decisions.  And, however illegitimate W. Bush's Iraq invasion was, he at least had to present Congress with a casus belli in the form of supposed WMDs.  It was a lie, of course, but it was seen at the time as a casus belli.  There is absolutely zero justification for an annexation of Greenland.  Then there's the American public and voters.  Not only is there no public support for an invasion of Greenland, but it's likely the fallout from such an annexation would be a crippling blow to the GOP in 2026 and 2028 because of the consequences of significant international backlash.    And at the end of the day, what will Trump have gained?  Access to Greenland's minerals and resources?  Not if military action is involved; any US exploitation of Greenland's resources would require cooperation from a wide variety of folks, from Greenlanders themselves to international corporations and consortiums.  If Greenland becomes a contested environment, it would be years before any kind of economic benefit could be seriously considered.  This is as self-defeating as a Chinese invasion of Taiwan.  Of course, with Trump as with Xi, that doesn't mean it isn't possible; it just means it's very unlikely.

Comment: Not particularly new, this has been a part of everyday speech in at the very least both American and Australian English for decades   The "yeah" and the "no" are responding to two different inferences.    "Yeah" in this case is meant to be read as a declarative statement, as in "yeah, I've made up my mind" and "no" is a response to the implied question of "Are you going to burn down my house?"
Author: thinginwoods

Comment: HAHA  In Canadian “Yeah, no” means no.   And “No, yeah” means yes.   “Yeah, no, yeah” means definitely.   “No, yeah, no”, means f—- no.  Hope that helps hahaha
